page.title: 04The Shore,Angmering-on-Sea.
page.content: The grey and brown pebbles slope gently to the sea, which at low tide leaves a wide expanse of sand. The strandline on the beach includes litter from the sea like seaweed, cuttlefish bones, egg cases of the common whelk and plastic bottles, paper and empty cans. Amongst the pebbles you can find empty slipper limpets, whelk, dog whelk and periwinkle shells discarded by their animal occupants. Due to wave action the larger pebbles are deposited near the top of the groyne section, these having been placed to avoid excessive beach erosion. On the exposed sand, lugworm casts. Various seaweeds, common squid eggs, sandhoppers and crabs were discovered. In summer common squid eggs may be washed ashore.
